10000001-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nWith a flat body and wide tail fin, this common fish can be caught just about anywhere.\nCommon: 20-30 cm, Big: 40 cm or bigger

10000002-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nIt looks like a regular crucian carp, but it's head is flatter and protrudes more.\nCommon: 20-30 cm, Big: 40 cm or bigger

10000003-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nIts name literally means "fish with teeth."\nCommon: 20-30 cm, Big: 40 cm or bigger

10000004-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nThe distinctive navy line travels all the way down its body.\nCommon: 1-4 cm, Big: 8 cm or bigger

10000005-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nToward the end of spring, it lays its eggs inside a clam's shell. It's a very popular aquarium fish.\nCommon: 5-10 cm, Big: 16 cm or bigger

10000006-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nWhen it's time to lay eggs, it coos like a pigeon.\nCommon: 1-4 cm, Big: 8 cm or bigger

10000007-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nIt prefers oxygen-rich waters. It looks similar to a trout.\nCommon: 15-20 cm, Big: 25 cm or bigger

10000008-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nThis hardy fish can withstand changes in temperature, salinity, or purity.\nCommon: 1-3 cm, Big: 5 cm or bigger

10000009-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nTiny but tough, it feeds mostly on microorganisms that dwell on stones or in the sand. It also enjoys the occasional insect.\nCommon: 1-4 cm, Big: 8 cm or bigger

10000010-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nFamous for its mustache, they say soups made from catfish are excellent for your health.\nCommon: 10-20 cm, Big: 30 cm or bigger

10000011-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nIt gets its name from the blue dot near its gills.\nCommon: 10-20 cm, Big: 30 cm or bigger

10000012-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nWhen it's time to lay eggs, it changes colors, stops eating, and swims back to the river where it was born.\nCommon: 40-60 cm, Big: 80 cm or bigger

10000013-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nThis type of salmon stays in the river and doesn't go to the ocean.\nCommon: 40-60 cm, Big: 80 cm or bigger

10000014-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nIt's ridiculously cute and can regenerate lost limbs.\nCommon: 10-20 cm, Big: 30 cm or bigger

10000015-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nJust like an axolotl, but with speckles! It's just as cute and can also regenerate lost limbs.\nCommon: 10-20 cm, Big: 30 cm or bigger

10000016-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nIf you put a bunch of them in a basket, they start bumping into each other. They tend to shake their tails.\nCommon: 1-2 cm, Big: 3 cm or bigger

10000017-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nIf you put a bunch of them in a basket, they start bumping into each other. They tend to shake their tails.\nCommon: 1-2 cm, Big: 3 cm or bigger

10000018-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nIt's a vicious predator that preys on other fish, eggs, and baby fish.\nCommon: 10-25 cm, Big: 50 cm or bigger

10000019-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nIt's delicious, loaded with nutrients, and gives you lots of energy!\nCommon: 50-60 cm, Big: 80 cm or bigger

10000020-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nThe black spots all over its body are splotchy and messy.\nCommon: 10-15 cm, Big: 20 cm or bigger

10000021-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nIt's very slippery, but it's high in protein.\nCommon: 10-15 cm, Big: 20 cm or bigger

10000022-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nThe patterns on this nocturnal fish look like they were carefully painted on by an artist.\nCommon: 10-15 cm, Big: 20 cm or bigger

10000023-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nA member of the carp family that's very sensitive to changes in the environment.\nCommon: 15-30 cm, Big: 40 cm or bigger

10000024-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nAn active eater that preys on shellfish and insects.\nCommon: 5-8 cm, Big: 15 cm or bigger

10000025-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nIt's called a "Leaf Fish" because of its flat, leaf-shaped body.\nCommon: 1-5 cm, Big: 10 cm or bigger

10000026-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nDuring mating season, the male prepares a nest to attract a female. Afterward, it stays and protects its eggs.\nCommon: 20-30 cm, Big: 40 cm or bigger

10000027-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nA fish specially bred to have a superior color, pattern, and even gloss.\nCommon: 50-60 cm, Big: 100 cm or bigger

10000028-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nThis elegant koi has black and red patterns all over its white body.\nCommon: 50-60 cm, Big: 100 cm or bigger

10000029-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nA stylish koi with the perfect blend of black patterns on its white body.\nCommon: 50-60 cm, Big: 100 cm or bigger

10000030-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nA beautiful koi that glimmers like pure gold.\nCommon: 50-60 cm, Big: 100 cm or bigger

10000031-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nThe spots on its back look like hundreds of eyeballs.\nCommon: 30-100 cm, Big: 200 cm or bigger

10000032-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nIt can live for many years, but because of the demand for caviar, they've become endangered.\nCommon: 40-60 cm, Big: 100 cm or bigger

10000033-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nIt's born in the ocean, but it eventually swims to a river and lives its out life there. Great for any dish, especially summer grilling.\nCommon: 50-70 cm, Big: 150 cm or bigger

10000034-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nA bream with a twirly fin and dopey smile.\nCommon: 10-20 cm, Big: 30 cm or bigger

10000035-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nIt has a tiny star close to its spiky dorsal fin. They're known to be fussy.\nCommon: 10-20 cm, Big: 30 cm or bigger

10000036-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nIts pectoral fin looks like a pair of wings. The big stripe makes it a popular aquarium fish.\nCommon: 30-50 cm, Big: 70 cm or bigger

10000037-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nThis fish always remains calm, even in the face of danger. It's the Empress's favorite fish.\nCommon: 10-20 cm, Big: 30 cm or bigger

10000038-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nIt's a baby turtle with broccoli on its back! They may be cute, but they bite, so watch your fingers.\nCommon: 50-100 cm, Big: 150 cm or bigger

10000039-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nAn ancient fish that's merged with plant life. You'll need to sail through time if you want to catch it!\nCommon: 500-800 cm, Big: 1000 cm or bigger

10000040-null-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nA mechanical shark that was made by an unknown blacksmith. It looks scary, but it's actually pretty harmless.\nCommon: 50-200 cm, Big:  400 cm or bigger

10000041-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nIt looks like a black tiger shrimp when young, but as it grows it develops a beautiful blue color.\nCommon: 10-15 cm, Big: 20 cm or bigger

10000042-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nThis fish won't stop sobbing. Seriously. Many anglers will throw these back into the water just to get it to shut up.\nCommon: 50-70 cm, Big: 80 cm or bigger

10000043-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nThis aquatic plant is a favorite treat for ducks.\nCommon: 1-2 cm, Big: 3 cm or bigger

10000044-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nIt's speckled when young, but develops a deep golden color in adulthood.\nCommon: 20-30 cm, Big: 40 cm or bigger

10000045-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nOnce it takes root, this plant lives a long time.\nCommon: 15-20 cm, Big: 25 cm or bigger

10000046-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nThe growth on its head looks like a leaf. It feels like a leaf. It even tastes like a leaf!\nCommon: 40-50 cm, Big: 60 cm or bigger

10000047-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nThe blossom on this fish's head draws insects, which it then happily chows down on.\nCommon: 40-50 cm, Big: 60 cm or bigger

10000048-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nThe blossom on this fish's head draws insects, which it then happily chows down on.\nCommon: 40-50 cm, Big: 60 cm or bigger

10000049-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nA transparent, soft fish that's almost like... jelly.\nCommon: 20-30 cm, Big: 40 cm or bigger

10000050-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nA transparent, soft fish that's almost like... jelly.\nCommon: 20-30 cm, Big: 40 cm or bigger

10000051-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nA fish that's bent like a bow. A favorite among the Green Hoods.\nCommon: 50-70 cm, Big: 150 cm or bigger

10000052-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nWhile the fins of this fish look like angel wings, it cannot fly.\nCommon: 15-25 cm, Big: 35 cm or bigger

10000053-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nA spotted jellyfish. It's exquisitely beautiful, but its tentacles carry a painful sting.\nCommon: 2-30 cm, Big: 40 cm or bigger

10000054-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nThis ginkgo-shaped stingray is found most commonly in the fall.\nCommon: 30-100 cm, Big: 200 cm or bigger

10000055-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nDid this fish descend from slimes? Or is this an example of convergent evolution?\nCommon: 70-100 cm, Big: 120 cm or bigger

10000056-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in freshwater rivers.\nIts scales shimmer and shine like a resplendent jewel.\nCommon: 5-10 cm, Big: 15 cm or bigger

10000057-null-null.name: Lives in clear, cold rivers. \nA big and friendly fish. It has bright eyes, with a red nose and red cheeks as if embarrassed. People love this fish. \nCommon: 700-1000 cm, Big: 1200 cm or bigger

11000001-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nWhen it spreads out its unusually large pectoral fins, it looks just like a butterfly.\nCommon: 10-15 cm, Big: 20 cm or bigger

11000002-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nThe end of its dorsal fin trails off into a thin string. Very popular in aquariums.\nCommon: 10-15 cm, Big: 20 cm or bigger

11000003-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIt's sometimes confused for the Blackback Butterflyfish, but true anglers can spot the difference instantly.\nCommon: 5-10 cm, Big: 15 cm or bigger

11000004-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nWith strong teeth and excellent eyes, this is a tough fish to land.\nCommon: 20-30 cm, Big: 40 cm or bigger

11000005-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIts dorsal fin is robust and sturdy.\nCommon: 20-30 cm, Big: 40 cm or bigger

11000006-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nThis fish is born a male and becomes a female when it matures. Whether grilled or boiled, it's always delicious.\nCommon: 15-25 cm, Big: 35 cm or bigger

11000007-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIts body is a deep crimson, and it has a noticeable underbite.\nCommon: 10-20 cm, Big: 30 cm or bigger

11000008-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nWhen it inflates, it sticks its spines out. Try not to get stung when you're taking it off the hook!\nCommon: 20-30 cm, Big: 40 cm or bigger

11000009-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nExtremely poisonous, but if you cook it right, it's one of the tastiest things you'll ever eat. Its poison gets more potent during spring.\nCommon: 40-50 cm, Big: 60 cm or bigger

11000010-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nRemove the poison completely before eating it. You can steam it, turn it into broth, or use it for a spicy stew!\nCommon: 1-5 cm, Big: 10 cm or bigger

11000011-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nThis delightful and super intelligent mammal lives in the ocean.\nCommon: 100-200 cm, Big: 450 cm or bigger

11000012-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nThe ultimate ocean predator. Intelligent and insanely strong, it passes on all of its hunting knowledge to its offspring.\nCommon: 500-700 cm, Big: 1000 cm or bigger

11000013-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nThis whale is known for its extraordinary ability to show sympathy. It even protects weaker fish from predators.\nCommon: 700-1100 cm, Big: 1600 cm or bigger

11000014-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIt has flat diamond-shaped body and a long tail with a poisonous tip. Try not to get stung!\nCommon: 50-100 cm, Big: 200 cm or bigger

11000017-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIt has a difficult, violent life throughout its infancy. Once it reaches adulthood, it dominates the ocean.\nCommon: 200-400 cm, Big: 650 cm or bigger

11000018-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nThe fastest of all shark species, it can live off of both fresh and rotting meat.\nCommon: 200-400 cm, Big: 600 cm or bigger

11000019-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nDespite its size, it's actually quite docile. It has white speckles on its back.\nCommon: 1200-1400 cm, Big: 1800 cm or bigger

11000020-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIt gets its name from the shape of its head. When dried, its fin can be used for cooking.\nCommon: 200-250 cm, Big: 350 cm or bigger

11000021-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nThis blueback lives in herds with fish of similar size. It's easy to catch, making it a common dish among most people.\nCommon: 10-20 cm, Big: 30 cm or bigger

11000022-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nWhen threatened, it spreads out its pectoral fins to make it look like it's flying.\nCommon: 20-25 cm, Big: 36 cm or bigger

11000023-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nResembling the curved blade of a cutlass, this fish is an excellent source of protein.\nCommon: 50-100 cm, Big: 150 cm or bigger

11000025-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nThough it can found in the deep sea, it prefers to live in clean waters. It's high in protein and low in fat.\nCommon: 70-100 cm, Big: 120 cm or bigger

11000026-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIts subtle flavors make it very versatile in cooking. It can be grilled, seared, or eaten as sashimi.\nCommon: 60-70 cm, Big: 80 cm or bigger

11000027-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nDepending on the season, this fish tastes differently. It's horrible in the summer, but in the winter, there's nothing tastier!\nCommon: 20-30 cm, Big: 50 cm or bigger

11000028-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nKnown for its uniquely spear-shaped mouth, it's usually either grilled or eaten in sushi.\nCommon: 200-300 cm, Big: 420 cm or bigger

11000029-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIt can be spiced, dried, or pickled. When dried, it's an excellent source of calcium.\nCommon: 1-2 cm, Big: 3 cm or bigger

11000030-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nThis scaleless fish is delicious when braised or grilled.\nCommon: 15-20 cm, Big: 26 cm or bigger

11000031-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIt's easily the tastiest of all cephalopods, and its bone can be used as a medicine to treat bleeding.\nCommon: 8-50 cm, Big: 100 cm or bigger

11000032-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIt can change its body color. Some of them even glow! Known to squirt ink in a pinch.\nCommon: 2-50 cm, Big: 100 cm or bigger

11000033-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nWith its eight wriggling tentacles, this extremely intelligent mollusk turns red and squirts a cloud of ink when it's threatened.\nCommon: 50-150 cm, Big: 300 cm or bigger

11000034-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIt doesn't have a very fishy smell and actually has a slightly sweet flavor. A very common sushi fish.\nCommon: 20-30 cm, Big: 40 cm or bigger

11000035-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIt travels with other sardines by the millions in breathtakingly large schools. It's sometimes called the "rice of the ocean" since it's on the bottom of the food chain.\nCommon: 15-20 cm, Big: 25 cm or bigger

11000036-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIt has a blue back and a silver-white belly. It's very tasty and often eaten as sashimi.\nCommon: 70-100 cm, Big: 150 cm or bigger

11000037-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nThe big, bulging eyes are the trademark of this metallic-looking fish.\nCommon: 5-10 cm, Big: 15 cm or bigger

11000038-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIt's very rare, very expensive, and very tasty.\nCommon: 50-80 cm, Big: 100 cm or bigger

11000039-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIt has a flat, egg-shaped body, and both of its eyes are on its right side.\nCommon: 15-50 cm, Big: 100 cm or bigger

11000040-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIt's body is flat and shaped like a diamond. It can be dried and made into jerky.\nCommon: 5-10 cm, Big: 20 cm or bigger

11000041-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nAs it grows, it'll leave behind its smaller shell in exchange for something more spacious.\nCommon: 3-5 cm, Big: 10 cm or bigger

11000042-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIt hides under rocks during the day and moves around at night. Its pincers are surprisingly powerful.\nCommon: 15-40 cm, Big: 60 cm or bigger

11000043-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nThis shrimp has a pleasantly chewy texture and is loaded with calcium. It has several brown stripes on its back.\nCommon: 5-15 cm, Big: 20 cm or bigger

11000044-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nUnlike other crabs, this one is an excellent swimmer. For some reason, females are most delicious during the early summer.\nCommon: 5-15 cm, Big: 20 cm or bigger

11000045-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nThis adorable and tiny fish was named for its horse-like appearance. They pair up with their mates for life, and the males give birth to the offspring!\nCommon: 1-5 cm, Big: 10 cm or bigger

11000046-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIt can use its flippers to quickly swim for long distances. A healthy one can live to be over 100 years old!\nCommon: 50-80 cm, Big: 120 cm or bigger

11000047-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nThe black spots on its back make it a very popular fish in aquariums.\nCommon: 20-40 cm, Big: 60 cm or bigger

11000048-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nThis unique, bug-eyed creature hops around on muddy shores in search of food.\nCommon: 10-13 cm, Big: 18 cm or bigger

11000049-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIt has long, slender body and no scales. Fairly easy to catch.\nCommon: 15-30 cm, Big: 60 cm or bigger

11000050-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIt's commonly used in sushi, but it also makes for a fantastic spicy fish stew.\nCommon: 20-30 cm, Big: 40 cm or bigger

11000051-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIt has bumps all over its long body, just like a cucumber.\nCommon: 10-20 cm, Big: 30 cm or bigger

11000052-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nSome people think it looks like a spiky chestnut. Pick it up gently so you don't poke yourself!\nCommon: 5-10 cm, Big: 15 cm or bigger

11000053-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nUnlike other starfish, this one doesn't attack clams. It cleans the ocean by scavenging on dead, rotten fish.\nCommon: 5-10 cm, Big: 20 cm or bigger

11000054-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIts five limbs form a distinct star shape, giving this sea creature its name. Whenever it loses a limb, it will grow it back over time.\nCommon: 10-20 cm, Big: 50 cm or bigger

11000055-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIts soft, squishy body resembles a mushroom or an umbrella. It has poisonous tendrils and will sting you if you make it angry!\nCommon: 2-30 cm, Big: 40 cm or bigger

11000056-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nSavory and packed with nutrients, this creature can contract and expand its body at will.\nCommon: 5-10 cm, Big: 15 cm or bigger

11000057-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIt's one of the starfish's only natural predators. If you drill a hole in the tip, you can use it as a trumpet!\nCommon: 10-20 cm, Big: 30 cm or bigger

11000058-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nHigh in calcium, this plant is thought to be very nutritious for new mothers.\nCommon: 50-100 cm, Big: 150 cm or bigger

11000059-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIt has two large, protruding eyes and poisonous fins.\nCommon: 15-25 cm, Big: 35 cm or bigger

11000060-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nOne of the most popular delicacies throughout history. Many people think it looks like chaos onyx.\nCommon: 5-10 cm, Big: 15 cm or bigger

11000061-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nCovered in tons of bumps, this creature somewhat resembles a red pineapple.\nCommon: 5-10 cm, Big: 18 cm or bigger

11000062-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIts shell looks like a fan. It tastes good grilled, in soup, or in sushi.\nCommon: 2-10 cm, Big: 15 cm or bigger

11000063-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIf you step on old, dried shells, they crunch loudly under your feet. It's super satisfying, but make sure it's not still alive when you step on it!\nCommon: 2-4 cm, Big: 6 cm or bigger

11000064-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nThe flesh of a mussel has a soft red tint to it. There's no better feeling like a bowl of hot mussel soup on a cold winter night!\nCommon: 5-14 cm, Big: 20 cm or bigger

11000065-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nWhen sand or other substances enter the shell, the oyster coats it in a defensive fluid. After layers of the fluid build up, a pearl is formed.\nCommon: 1-5 cm, Big: 10 cm or bigger

11000066-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nWith a menacing nose ring and a razor-sharp fringe on its back, this crocodile is one of the more formidable sea creatures.\nCommon: 100-300 cm, Big: 500 cm or bigger

11000067-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nThought to be long extinct, this fish was cursed by a witch many years ago, giving it an odd face that looks like a mask.\nCommon: 100-300 cm, Big: 500 cm or bigger

11000068-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIt always looks like it's blushing, and when it gets too embarrassed, it runs away. It's a horrible pirate.\nCommon: 100-300 cm, Big: 500 cm or bigger

11000069-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nThe black and white stripes, natural burglar mask, and shackles give this shady fish its name.\nCommon: 100-300 cm, Big: 500 cm or bigger

11000070-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nIts savage appearance earned it the nickname "Terror of the Deep." The angrier it gets, the brighter the light on its lure glows.\nCommon: 100-300 cm, Big: 500 cm or bigger

11000071-null-null.name:
Lives in the ocean around Harang Island. 
Yoharang in Evansville can tell you how to get there.
Aside from its striking gold color, this fish has a distinct dorsal fin that looks just like a pineapple.
Common: 10-20 cm, Big: 30 cm or bigger

11000072-null-null.name:
Lives in the ocean around Harang Island. 
Yoharang in Evansville can tell you how to get there.
It's famous for the little stars on its back.
Common: 10-20 cm, Big: 30 cm or bigger

11000073-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nThis powerful fish is difficult to keep on a line, but the exhilaration of catching it makes it well worth it.\nCommon: 50-100 cm, Big: 200 cm or longer.

11000074-null-null.name: Lives in the ocean.\nA rare axolotl covered in flowers. They say that if you land a prize catch, your future will be like a walk through a garden.\nCommon: 10-20 cm, Big 30 cm or longer.

12000001-null-null.name: Lives in liquid hot magma.\nIt looks much angrier than a regular piranha. It's hot to the touch.\nCommon: 20-30 cm, Big: 40 cm or bigger

12000002-null-null.name: Lives in liquid hot magma.\nLike a normal stringray, it's flat with a long tail. The flame on its tail leaves a trail of steam behind it when it coasts on the surface.\nCommon: 50-100 cm, Big: 200 cm or bigger

12000003-null-null.name: Lives in liquid hot magma.\nUnlike its docile cousin, this whale shark is confrontational and violent.\nCommon: 1200-1400 cm, Big: 1800 cm or bigger

12000004-null-null.name: Lives in liquid hot magma.\nThis bass swallowed lava and somehow survived. It developed thick scales as a result, and now it can swim freely through lava.\nCommon: 10-25 cm, Big: 50 cm or bigger

12000005-null-null.name: Lives in liquid hot magma.\nIt uses the same process to make pearls as a regular pearl oyster, except that it uses lava. Red pearls are said to possess mysterious power.\nCommon: 1-5 cm, Big: 10 cm or bigger

12000006-null-null.name: Lives in liquid hot magma.\nThis seaweed species thrives in a molten environment. It quickly shrivels up when removed from the safety of the lava.\nCommon: 50-100 cm, Big: 150 cm or bigger

12000007-null-null.name: Lives in liquid hot magma.\nInstead of poison, it shoots out bits of lava when it's angry. It's angry quite often, so watch out!\nCommon: 1-5 cm, Big: 10 cm or bigger

12000008-null-null.name: Lives in liquid hot magma.\nWhen it swims close to the surface of the lava, it produces a nutty, salty smell.\nCommon: 5-10 cm, Big: 20 cm or bigger

12000009-null-null.name: Lives in liquid hot magma.\nIt closely resembles the panther grouper, except it's red. The black spots on its body get bigger when threatened.\nCommon: 20-40 cm, Big: 60 cm or bigger

12000010-null-null.name: Lives in liquid hot magma.\nIts scales became stronger and thicker over time to withstand the scorching magma. Its fin is slightly pointier than its oceanic cousin.\nCommon: 15-20 cm, Big: 26 cm or bigger

12000011-null-null.name: Lives in liquid hot magma.\nIt's naturally incredibly spicy, so there's no need to add any pepper while cooking it. For serious spicy food lovers only!\nCommon: 5-15 cm, Big: 20 cm or bigger

12000012-null-null.name: Lives in liquid hot magma.\nCompared to other lava-dwelling fish, it's pretty docile.\nCommon: 1-4 cm, Big: 8 cm or bigger

12000013-null-null.name: Lives in liquid hot magma.\nA close relative of the ricefish, this fish is a common find when fishing in lava.\nCommon: 1-3 cm, Big: 5 cm or bigger

12000014-null-null.name: Lives in liquid hot magma.\nIt has the sharpest teeth among all sharks. If you see it, turn the other way.\nCommon: 200-400 cm, Big: 650 cm or bigger

12000015-null-null.name: Lives in liquid hot magma.\nKnown for its sword-like snout, this marlin has a deep stripe that spans its entire body.\nCommon: 200-300 cm, Big: 420 cm or bigger

12000016-null-null.name: Lives in liquid hot magma.\nThe devilish wings on this seahorse make it a popular pet among demons.\nCommon: 1-5 cm, Big: 10 cm or bigger

12000017-null-null.name: Lives in liquid hot magma.\nIt's so rare that most anglers live their whole lives without ever laying eyes on it. It's Balrog's favorite delicacy.\nCommon: 100-500 cm, Big: 1000 cm or bigger

12000018-null-null.name: Lives in liquid hot magma.\nThe mane on the back of its neck burns for as long as it lives.\nCommon: 100-500 cm, Big: 1000 cm or bigger

12000019-null-null.name: Lives in liquid hot magma.\nA seahorse that closely resembles Horus. It uses its demonic wings to flap through the lava.\nCommon: 10-50 cm, Big: 70 cm or bigger

12000020-null-null.name:
Lives in the liquid hot magma of Harang Island.
Yoharang in Evansville can tell you how to get there.
It was first discovered after a volcano erupted at the bottom of the ocean. Its dragon-like body appears to be on fire.
Common: 10-50 cm, Big: 70 cm or bigger

12000021-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in liquid hot magma.\nThe leaves of this magma-based plant look like burning flames. The leaves are safe to touch... if you can get them out of the lava!\nCommon: 1-2 cm, Big: 3 cm or bigger

12000022-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in liquid hot magma.\nThe stings of this jellyfish feel like burning flames.\nCommon: 2-30 cm, Big: 40 cm or bigger

12000023-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in liquid hot magma.\nThe stripes across this bream's body are reminiscent of bubbling lava.\nCommon: 15-30 cm, Big: 40 cm or bigger

12000024-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in liquid hot magma.\nThis creature's body is covered in long, sharp spikes. The red core, however, is quite soft.\nCommon: 15-20 cm, Big: 25 cm or bigger.

12000025-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in liquid hot magma.\nThis fish is a close relative of the curse eye. Its skin is hot to the touch.\nCommon: 50-60 cm, Big: 100 cm or bigger

13000003-null-null.name: Lives in waters tainted by evil.\nThe pincers on this lobsters are large, poisonous, and saw-toothed, so watch out!\nCommon: 5-15 cm, Big: 20 cm or bigger

13000005-null-null.name: Lives in waters tainted by evil.\nYou might be tempted to pet it because it's so cute, but it's actually pretty vicious and will bite your fingers off. Unlike you, it can easily regenerate lost limbs.\nCommon: 10-20 cm, Big: 30 cm or bigger

13000007-null-null.name: Lives in waters tainted by evil.\nThis rare and exotic whale shines a brilliant shade of violet. It has a pair of fins that look like wings.\nCommon: 700-1100 cm, Big: 1600 cm or bigger

13000009-null-null.name: Lives in waters tainted by evil.\nDespite living in corrupted waters, this graceful seahorse sports a pair of fins that look like angel wings.\nCommon: 1-5 cm, Big: 10 cm or bigger

13000010-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in waters tainted by evil.\nA fish that lives in the darkest corners of the water. Its eyes no longer function.\nCommon: 100-300 cm, Big: 500 cm or bigger

13000011-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in waters tainted by evil.\nThis slime fish looks like it's been taking its evil pills.\nCommon: 70-100 cm, Big: 120 cm or bigger

13000012-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in waters tainted by evil.\nBecause its body is translucent, this fish has a tendency to sneak up on and surprise divers.\nCommon: 30-40 cm, Big: 50 cm or bigger

13000013-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in waters tainted by evil.\nThis odd blob's body is specially adapted for buoyancy.\nCommon: 30-40 cm, Big: 50 cm or bigger

13000014-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in waters tainted by evil.\nThis shrimp may come from evil waters, but it tastes incredible.\nCommon: 20-25 cm, Big: 30 cm or bigger

13000015-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in waters tainted by evil.\nThis aetherine clam has been corrupted by evil, turning it dark and red.\nCommon: 20-30 cm, Big: 50 cm or bigger

13000016-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in waters tainted by evil.\nThis aetherine conch has been corrupted by evil, turning it dark and red.\nCommon: 20-30 cm, Big: 50 cm or bigger

13000017-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in waters tainted by evil.\nThis aetherine stingray has been corrupted by evil, turning it dark and red.\nCommon: 50-150 cm, Big: 300 cm or bigger

14000001-null-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nIt feeds off of insects that can only be found in poisonous water.\nCommon: 5-10 cm, Big: 15 cm or bigger

14000002-null-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nIt has a horrible memory. It hates poison, but it keeps forgetting that it lives in it.\nCommon: 50-60 cm, Big: 80 cm or bigger

14000003-null-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nIts shell looks like its decaying. Often found hiding between rocks and plants.\nCommon: 15-40 cm, Big: 60 cm or bigger

14000004-null-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nFound deep in the mud beneath toxic water. When it surfaces, everything will try to eat it.\nCommon: 2-4 cm, Big: 6 cm or bigger

14000005-null-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nThis species of starfish destroys the ecosystem wherever it's introduced. It uses its decaying, poisonous tendrils to hunt and feed on clams.\nCommon: 5-10 cm, Big: 20 cm or bigger

14000006-null-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nIf you can properly remove all of its poison, it actually tastes better than a regular drum.\nCommon: 40-60 cm, Big: 90 cm or bigger

14000007-null-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nIt's always bloated because of the poison.\nCommon: 50-80 cm, Big: 100 cm or bigger

14000008-null-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nIt isn't really a type of suckerfish, as the name might imply. It actually gets its name because it's extremely stupid, even for a fish.\nCommon: 50-80 cm, Big: 100 cm or bigger

14000009-null-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nA type of butterflyfish. The murky waters it lives in gave it that smoky color.\nCommon: 10-20 cm, Big: 30 cm or bigger

14000010-null-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nInstead of ink, this deathly creature squirts poison when threatened.\nCommon: 2-50 cm, Big: 100 cm or bigger

14000011-null-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nA type of flounder that loves to bury itself in the poisonous mud deep beneath the water.\nCommon: 15-50 cm, Big: 100 cm or bigger

14000012-null-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nIt doesn't look very appetizing, but it's a highly sought-after ingredient used in many fine dishes.\nCommon: 5-10 cm, Big: 18 cm or bigger

14000013-null-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nThe potent poison that's soaked inside the shell has to be completely removed before eating.\nCommon: 10-20 cm, Big: 30 cm or bigger

14000014-null-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nThe poison has given its shell a rusted, grayish color.\nCommon: 5-14 cm, Big: 20 cm or bigger

14000015-null-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nIt has a natural resistance to toxins. The fin closest to the front of its head is slightly longer than its cousin's.\nCommon: 1-5 cm, Big: 10 cm or bigger

14000016-null-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nBecause it lives in poison, it's always depressed and on the verge of tears.\nCommon: 1-5 cm, Big: 10 cm or bigger

14000017-null-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nInstead of ink, this deathly creature squirts poison when threatened.\nCommon: 50-150 cm, Big: 300 cm or bigger

14000018-null-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nUnlike the flathead grey mullet, this fish is tastiest during the summer. Make sure you get rid of all the poison first!\nCommon: 20-30 cm, Big: 50 cm or bigger

14000019-null-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nDon't be fooled by its ridiculous looks. It's actually quite intelligent and difficult to catch.\nCommon: 20-30 cm, Big: 50 cm or bigger

14000020-null-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nShort-tempered, impatient, and easily stressed out.\nCommon: 20-30 cm, Big: 50 cm or bigger

14000021-null-null.name:
Lives in the foul, poisonous water of Harang Island.
Yoharang in Evansville can tell you how to get there.
An adorable creature despite its hostile environment. It's unknown whether the petal-like scales are a product of nature or contamination.
Common: 20-30 cm, Big: 50 cm or bigger

14000022-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nIts spear-like snout is distinctive. While it's dangerous to eat raw, the poison boils away when cooked.\nCommon: 200-300 cm, Big: 420 cm or bigger

14000023-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nAbalones are prized among seafaring gourmets. This one will give you a nasty rash.\nCommon: 5-10 cm, Big: 15 cm or bigger

14000024-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nCatfish make a healthy meal when simmered for a long time. Not this one, though.\nCommon: 10-20 cm, Big: 30 cm or bigger

14000025-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nThis fish is the spitting image of a curse eye. Be sure to remove the venom sac before serving.\nCommon: 50-60 cm, Big: 100 cm or bigger

14000026-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nLives in crevices and eats plankton. Unlike other barnacles, these are not safe for consumption.\nCommon: 1-5 cm, Big: 6 cm or bigger

14000027-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nIt's covered in sharp spines even thicker than those of a sea urchin, making it particularly difficult to handle.\nCommon: 15-20 cm, Big: 25 cm or bigger.

14000028-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nThis fish subsists on the sheddings left behind by Gigantica.\nCommon: 50-80 cm, Big: 100 cm or bigger

14000029-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in foul, poisonous waters.\nThis fish follows Gigantica around, eating its refuse. It's like Gigantica's tail in more ways than one!\nCommon: 50-80 cm, Big: 120 cm or bigger

15000001-null-null.name: Lives in rich, sticky oil.\nIts keen eyesight allows it to roam freely through oil. No matter how well you clean its shell, it's always slippery.\nCommon: 5-10 cm, Big: 25 cm or bigger

15000002-null-null.name: Lives in rich, sticky oil.\nIt has the ability to purify oil. When you cut open its belly, it's surprisingly oil-free.\nCommon: 50-150 cm, Big: 300 cm or bigger

15000003-null-null.name: Lives in rich, sticky oil.\nIt's highly adaptable to its surroundings and can survive even in the murkiest oil.\nCommon: 5-10 cm, Big: 25 cm or bigger

15000004-null-null.name: Lives in rich, sticky oil.\nSurprisingly, the longer it soaks in oil, the tastier it is. Make sure to clean it thoroughly to remove any bacteria.\nCommon: 5-10 cm, Big: 25 cm or bigger

15000005-null-null.name: Lives in rich, sticky oil.\nWhen threatened, it releases a poisonous mixture of oil and ink before making its escape.\nCommon: 100-150 cm, Big: 500 cm or bigger

16000001-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in emerald waters.\nThis mechanical fish is powered by aetherine.\nCommon: 20-30 cm, Big: 50 cm or bigger

16000002-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in emerald waters.\nThis mechanical fish is powered by aetherine.\nCommon: 20-30 cm, Big: 50 cm or bigger

16000003-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in emerald waters.\nThis mechanical fish is powered by aetherine.\nCommon: 50-150 cm, Big: 300 cm or bigger

16000004-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in emerald waters.\nThis fish is named for its frilly fins.\nCommon: 20-30 cm, Big: 40 cm or bigger

16000005-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in emerald waters.\nThis fish is named for its frilly fins.\nCommon: 20-30 cm, Big: 40 cm or bigger

16000006-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in emerald waters.\nA strange green light emanates from between this fish's scales.\nCommon: 30-40 cm, Big: 50 cm or bigger

16000007-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in emerald waters.\nThis shy critter uses its shell to hide from predators—and awkward social situations.\nCommon: 5-10 cm, Big: 15 cm

16000008-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in emerald waters.\nWith its full lips and ruffled fins, it's hard to tell if you're looking at a fish or a dancer.\nCommon: 40-50 cm, Big: 60 cm or bigger

16000009-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in emerald waters.\nThe colorful scales of this seahorse makes it a prize for any aquarium.\nCommon: 1-5 cm, Big: 10 cm or bigger

16000010-Fishing02-null.name: Lives in emerald waters.\nThis unique creature calls to mind the castles of old. Rumor has it that its insides are filled with cogwheels.\nCommon: 100-150 cm, Big: 500 cm or bigger

99000001-null-null.name: This resilient creature can live in any type of water. Use the Beginner's Golden Lure to catch it more easily. Its flat, golden tail is about as wide as the thickest part of its body.\nCommon: 1-3 cm, Big: 5 cm or longer.

99000002-null-null.name: This resilient organism can live in any type of water. Use the Beginner's Golden Lure to catch it more easily. It sways back and forth under the waves, glittering on bright, clear days. Divers often confuse it for real gold.\nCommon: 50-100 cm, Big: 150 cm or longer.

99000003-null-null.name: This resilient creature can live in any type of water. Use the Beginner's Golden Lure to catch it more easily. Its round, golden head and long tentacles make it a mesmerizing spectacle to encounter.\nCommon: 50-150 cm, Big: 300 cm or longer.

99000004-null-null.name: This resilient creature can live in any type of water. Use the Veteran's Golden Bait to catch it more easily. Except for its white underbelly, most of its body is covered in elegant, golden scales.\nCommon: 10-20 cm, Big: 30 cm or longer.

99000005-null-null.name: This resilient creature can live in any type of water. Use the Veteran's Golden Bait to catch it more easily. Their golden shells are often used as horns by royalty.\nCommon: 3-5 cm, Big: 10 cm or longer.

99000006-null-null.name: This resilient creature can live in any type of water. Use the Veteran's Golden Bait to catch it more easily. It's often called the "sun of the sea" because of its radiant, golden luster.\nCommon: 10-20 cm, Big: 50 cm or longer.

99000007-null-null.name: This resilient creature can live in any type of water. Use the Expert's Golden Bait to catch it more easily. Its big, golden pincers sell for a very high price.\nCommon: 15-40 cm, Big: 60 cm or longer.

99000008-null-null.name: This resilient creature can live in any type of water. Use the Expert's Golden Bait to catch it more easily. It's considered very lucky, and many people believe it brings magical blessings.\nCommon: 5-10 cm, Big: 15 cm or longer.

99000009-null-null.name: This resilient creature can live in any type of water. Use the Expert's Golden Bait to catch it more easily. As a symbol of longevity, it's a perfect gift for new parents.\nCommon: 50-80 cm, Big: 120 cm or longer.

99000010-null-null.name: This resilient creature can live in any type of water. Use the Master's Golden Bait to lure it. Believed to be a good-luck charm, sailors often carry one with them on long voyages.\nCommon: 1-5 cm, Big: 10 cm or longer.

99000011-null-null.name: This resilient creature can live in any type of water. Use the Master's Golden Bait to lure it. It houses a huge golden egg rather than a pearl.\nCommon: 1-5 cm, Big: 10 cm or longer.

99000012-null-null.name: This resilient creature can live in any type of water. Use the Master's Golden Bait to lure it. It radiates with a mystical golden light. A mere glimpse of this creature is said to bring a lifetime of good fortune.\nCommon: 1200-1400 cm, Big: 1800 cm or longer.

99000025-null-null.name: This resilient creature can live in any type of water. Use the Pro's Golden Bait to lure it. It houses a huge golden egg instead of a pearl.\nCommon: 1-3 cm, Big: 5 cm or longer.

99000026-null-null.name: This resilient creature can live in any type of water. Use the Champion's Golden Bait to lure it. It radiates with a mystical golden light. A mere glimpse of this creature is said to bring a lifetime of good fortune.\nCommon: 50-100 cm, Big: 150 cm or longer.
